BetterDeal package¶

This "BetterDeal" directory is the actual Python package for our project. Its name is the Python package name we need to use to import anything inside it. (Django docs)

Submodules¶

1. BetterDeal.asgi module¶

Django supports deploying on ASGI, the emerging Python standard for asynchronous web servers and applications. Django’s startproject management command sets up a default ASGI configuration which can be found here and which we can tweak as needed for our project, and direct any ASGI-compliant application server to use. (Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/howto/deployment/asgi/) Right now it is unused.

2. BetterDeal.settings module¶

This settings file contains all the configuration of our Django installation, it is just a Python module with module-level variables. It does not have to define any settings if it does not need to, each setting has a sensible default value. (Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/settings/)

  • BASE_DIR: Our Django project directory.
  • SECRET_KEY: This is used to provide cryptographic signing, and should be set to a unique, unpredictable value.
  • DEBUG: A boolean that turns on/off debug mode. One of the main features of debug mode is the display of detailed error pages. If the app raises an exception when DEBUG is True, Django will display a detailed traceback, including a lot of metadata about the environment, such as all the currently defined Django settings (from settings.py).
  • ALLOWED_HOSTS: A list of strings representing the host/domain names that this Django site can serve. This is a security measure to prevent HTTP Host header attacks, which are possible even under many seemingly-safe web server configurations.
  • INSTALLED_APPS: A list of strings designating all applications that are enabled in the current Django installation.
  • MIDDLEWARE: Middleware is a framework of hooks into Django’s request/response processing. It’s a light, low-level “plugin” system for globally altering Django’s input or output.
  • ROOT_URLCONF: A string representing the full Python import path to your root URLconf, for example "mydjangoapps.urls".
  • TEMPLATES: A list containing the settings for all template engines to be used with Django.
  • WSGI_APPLICATION: The full Python path of the WSGI application object that Django’s built-in servers (e.g. runserver) will use
  • DATABASES: A dictionary containing the settings for all databases to be used with Django.
  • AUTH_PASSWORD_VALIDATORS: The list of validators that are used to check the strength of user’s passwords.
  • LANGUAGE_CODE: A string representing the language code for the installation, English is "en-us".
  • TIME_ZONE: A string representing the time zone for the database connection.
  • USE_I18N: A boolean that specifies whether Django’s translation system should be enabled.
  • USE_L10N: A boolean that specifies if localized formatting of data will be enabled by default or not. If this is set to True, e.g. Django will display numbers and dates using the format of the current locale.
  • USE_TZ: A boolean that specifies if datetimes will be timezone-aware by default or not. If this is set to True, Django will use timezone-aware datetimes internally.
  • STATIC_URL: URL to use when referring to static files located in STATIC_ROOT, including static files like CSS, JavaScript and Images.
  • STATICFILES_DIRS: This should be set to a list of strings that contain full paths to the additional files directory(ies).
  • DEFAULT_AUTO_FIELD: Default primary key field type to use for models that don’t have a field with primary_key=True.
  • LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL: The URL or named URL pattern where requests are redirected after login
  • LOGIN_URL: The URL or named URL pattern where requests are redirected for login

3. BetterDeal.urls module¶

The `urlpatterns` list routes URLs to views. (For more details: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/topics/http/urls/)

4. BetterDeal.wsgi module¶

Django’s primary deployment platform is WSGI, the Python standard for web servers and applications. Django’s startproject management command sets up a minimal default WSGI configuration for us, which we can tweak as needed for the project, and direct any WSGI-compliant application server to use. (Django docs: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.2/howto/deployment/wsgi/) Right now it is unused.
